profile_positions.company: CREATIVE KOREA: Exploring Contemporary Korean Cultural Industries and Cultural Production
profile_positions.description:
Presented at the 2023 CREATIVE KOREA conference in Bologna.

Presented an original paper on the topic of Korean cultural production, user-generated content on social media, and ‘Brand Korea.' This paper argues that the cultural branding of Korea for global consumption is now expanding further than mainstream media production and lifestyles products, with ordinary residents of Korea both contributing to and capitalising on Korea’s global visibility by posting aspects of their daily lives on social media. In particular, this paper is focused on lifestyle content that hinges on the more mundane or banal aspects of daily life in Korea, such as TikToks showcasing convenience store food or vlogs detailing different amenities in Korea, such as gyms, recycling, and libraries. The Korean-ness of these mundane activities is amplified by their creators, turning the mundane into aspirational content for audiences and consumers of Korean Wave products. Most significantly, this new trend in the expansion of the Korean Wave encourages the average Korean social media user (or even visitors to Korea) to brand themselves according to Hallyu logics, in particular given the increase in social media interaction and visibility that association with Hallyu and Brand-Korea can bring. However, while these social media users/content creators may benefit in terms of metrics and advertising revenue, these efforts ultimately feed into the larger, cross-industry branding efforts of South Korea. These creators are encouraged to present a certain vision of life in Korea, wherein an acceptable Korean self is one that adheres to the trends and norms of the Korean entertainment and lifestyle industry. The fantasy of K-Dramas and K-Pop alone can no longer drive the global expansion of Korean content, Korean life must now also replicate the fantasy constructed by the Korean wave.

profile_positions.description:
2022 Situations International Conference
 
Global Content Provider: Korean Film and TV Drama as Industry and Entertainment

Presented a paper entitled '(Teasing) Intimacy and Scandal in Singles Inferno: Tracing the Tension Between Global Formats and Cultural Norms in Korean Reality Dating Programmes'

‘This doesn’t feel like a Korean dating show!’ - host Hong Jin-kyung’s introduction to Netflix’s newest Korean reality series, Singles Inferno (솔로지옥 2021), explicitly emphasises the show’s ‘foreign’ feel. This ‘foreignness’ stems in part from the shows provocative premise, placing a number of objectively attractive and single individuals on a deserted island where they will battle it out in the name of romance. Echoing popular global reality formats from Love Island to The Bachelor in Paradise, the supposed ‘foreignness’ of Singles Inferno is linked not just to popular Western reality television conventions, but specifically the sexual and scandalous content these series are famed for. And yet, despite this initial teasing of a show unlike any other Korean reality series to date, Singles Inferno remains a largely conservative and uncontroversial production, where intimacy is teased but never realised. This paper aims to trace the balancing act that is preserving the excitement, drama, and scandal expected of global reality dating series without compromising the traditional morals and conservative norms that continue to define Korean television production. While the show itself navigates this terrain through editing and panel commentary, I will also demonstrate how the coalescence of conservatism and neoliberal competition causes new forms of scandal to arise. These tensions surrounding the process of localisation also point to larger discussions around the power dynamics at work within an increasingly platformised media context.

profile_positions.description:
Speaker at the South Korean Women's Cinema Conference hosted by the Academy of Korean Studies at Sheffield Hallam University (23th-25th September 2021). 

Presented a paper entitled 'The (Dis)Articulation of the Korean Woman: Contradictory Expressions of Women's Agency in The Woman Who Ran' and 'Kim Jiyoung, Born 1982,'' as part of a panel on 'Women's Agency in Male-Directed Films.'

The paper explored diverging aesthetic approaches to the expression of women's agency in two contemporaneous South Korean films, examining how they aim to create spaces for the collective articulation, mourning, and enhancement of women’s realities. Although both films offer a challenge to the ‘abstraction of women’ in South Korean cinema (Doane 1990), their efforts produce different results; while 'Kim Jiyoung, Born 1982' follows in the footsteps of the melodramatic ‘women’s film,’ 'The Woman Who Ran' takes a much more subdued approach, presenting three conversations between women with very little filmic intervention. The paper demonstrates how these different aesthetic interventions serve to either re-articulate womanhoods that adhere to the typical abstraction of the Korean woman, or dis-articulate the dominant tropes of Korean womanhood.

profile_positions.description: Community Support Representative role within Uber’s Incident Response Team, assisting riders, drivers, and delivery partners faced with safety related incidents. Provided specialist assistance to app-users in Sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in the case of high-level incidents. This position involved communicating effectively with both clients and stakeholders in order to resolve safety related incidents. Role involved both written and telephone communication with clients from across Europe and Africa, and required the ability to adapt and adjust communication to suit the needs of individual regions. Position also required research and problem solving skills in order to address and resolve complex and serious safety related incidents. The position also required flexibility in order to efficiently work across different regions with different regulations, as well as the ability to work under pressure.
